entry.title: Precision Matrices, Partial Correlations, and Conditional Independence

link.title: Precision Matrices, Partial Correlations, and Conditional Independence

entry.content:
In this post, we explore how the precision (inverse covariance) matrix for a Gaussian distribution encodes conditional dependence relations between the underlying variables. We also introduce the notions of conditional and partial correlation, and prove their equivalence in the Gaussian setting. Ideas along these lines are widely used in areas such as probabilistic graphical models (e.g., Gaussian Markov random fields and scalable Gaussian processes) and high-dimensional covariance estimation. A natural complement to this topic is my post on the Cholesky decomposition of a covariance matrix, which provides an alternate route to analyzing conditional dependence structure. The main source for this post is (Lauritzen, 2019), which is freely available online and provides an excellent rigorous introduction to graphical models in statistics.

Setup and Notation

Throughout this post we consider a set of random variables x1,…,xnx_1, \dots, x_nx1​,…,xn​, each taking values in R\mathbb{R}R. For an (ordered) index set A⊆{1,…,n}A \subseteq \{1,\dots,n\}A⊆{1,…,n}, we write xAx_AxA​ to denote the column vector [xi]i∈A[x_i]_{i \in A}[xi​]i∈A​ that retains the ordering of AAA. We will use the convention that B:={1,…,n}∖AB := \{1,\dots,n\} \setminus AB:={1,…,n}∖A is the complement of AAA, and use the shorthand x∼ix_{\sim i}x∼i​ for the vector of all variables excluding xix_ixi​. We also write xi⊥xj∣xBx_i \perp x_j|x_Bxi​⊥xj​∣xB​ to mean that xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​ are conditionally independent given xBx_BxB​.

The Precision Matrix of a Gaussian

In this section we will explore how the precision matrix of a Gaussian distribution is closely related to the conditional dependence structure of the random variables x1,…,xnx_1, \dots, x_nx1​,…,xn​. Throughout this section, we assume x=(x1,…,xn)⊤∼N(m,C),(1) x = (x_1, \dots, x_n)^\top \sim \mathcal{N}(m, C), \tag{1} x=(x1​,…,xn​)⊤∼N(m,C),(1) where CCC is positive definite. Hence, it is invertible, and we denote its inverse by P:=C−1,(2) P := C^{-1}, \tag{2} P:=C−1,(2) which we refer to as the precision matrix. The precision inherits positive definiteness from CCC. In some contexts (e.g., (Lauritzen, 2019)), PPP is also called the concentration matrix.

Throughout this section, our focus will be on the dependence between two variables xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​, conditional on all others. Thus, let’s define the index sets A:={i,j}A := \{i,j\}A:={i,j} and B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}B := \{1,\dots,n\} \setminus \{i,j\}B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}. We partition the joint Gaussian (1) (after possibly reordering the variables) as \begin{align} \begin{bmatrix} x_A \newline x_B \end{bmatrix} &\sim \mathcal{N}\left( \begin{bmatrix} m_A \newline m_B \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} C_A & C_{AB} \newline C_{BA} & C_B \end{bmatrix} \right). \tag{3} \end{align}

Our focus is thus on the conditional distribution of xA∣xBx_A|x_BxA​∣xB​. We recall that conditionals of Gaussians are themselves Gaussian, and that the conditional covariance takes the form CA∣B:=Cov[xA∣xB]=CA−CABCB−1CBA.(4) C_{A|B} := \text{Cov}[x_A|x_B] = C_A - C_{AB}C_B^{-1}C_{BA}. \tag{4} CA∣B​:=Cov[xA​∣xB​]=CA​−CAB​CB−1​CBA​.(4) I go through these derivations in depth in this post. For our present purposes, it is important to appreciate the connection between the conditional covariance (4) and the joint precision PPP. To this end, let’s consider partitioning the precision in the same manner as the covariance: \begin{align} P &= C^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} P_A & P_{AB} \newline P_{BA} & P_B \end{bmatrix}. \tag{5} \end{align} The above blocks of PPP can be obtained via a direct application of partitioned matrix inverse identities from linear algebra (see, e.g., James E. Pustejovsky’s post for some nice background). Applying the partitioned matrix identity to (5) yields \begin{align} P_A &= (C_A - C_{AB}C_B^{-1}C_{BA})^{-1} \tag{6} \newline P_{AB} &= -C_B^{-1} C_{BA}P_A. \tag{7} \end{align} Notice in (6) that PAP_APA​, the upper-left block of the joint precision, is precisely equal to the inverse of the conditional covariance CA∣BC_{A|B}CA∣B​ given in (4). We denote this conditional precision by PA∣B:=(CA∣B)−1.(8) P_{A|B} := (C_{A|B})^{-1}. \tag{8} PA∣B​:=(CA∣B​)−1.(8) We summarize this important connection below.

Joint and Conditional Precision.
The precision matrix of the conditional distribution xA∣xBx_A|x_BxA​∣xB​ is given by PA∣B=(CA∣B)−1=PA.(9) P_{A|B} = (C_{A|B})^{-1} = P_A. \tag{9} PA∣B​=(CA∣B​)−1=PA​.(9) In words, the conditional precision is obtained by deleting the rows and columns of the joint precision PPP that involve the conditioning variables xBx_BxB​.

This connection also leads us to our main result, which states that conditional independence can be inferred from zero entries of the precision matrix. This result follows immediately by rearranging (9) to CA∣B=(PA)−1(10) C_{A|B} = (P_A)^{-1} \tag{10} CA∣B​=(PA​)−1(10) and noting that (PA)−1(P_A)^{-1}(PA​)−1 is simply a two-by-two matrix that we can consider inverting by hand.

Zeros in Precision imply Conditional Independence.
An entry PijP_{ij}Pij​, i≠ji \neq ji​=j of the joint precision matrix is zero if and only if xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​ are conditionally independent, given all other variables. That is, Pij=0  ⟺  Cov[xi,xj∣xB]=0  ⟺  xi⊥xj∣xB,(11) P_{ij} = 0 \iff \text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B] = 0 \iff x_i \perp x_j | x_B, \tag{11} Pij​=0⟺Cov[xi​,xj​∣xB​]=0⟺xi​⊥xj​∣xB​,(11) where B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}B := \{1, \dots, n\} \setminus \{i,j\}B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}.

Proof. Setting A:={i,j}A := \{i,j\}A:={i,j}, the above derivation showed CA∣B=(PA)−1C_{A|B} = (P_A)^{-1}CA∣B​=(PA​)−1, where PAP_APA​ is the two-by-two block of the joint precision PPP corresponding to the variables xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​. Thus, Cov[xi,xj∣xB]=[CA∣B]12=0  ⟺  [(PA)−1]12=0. \text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B] = [C_{A|B}]_{12} = 0 \iff [(P_A)^{-1}]_{12} = 0. Cov[xi​,xj​∣xB​]=[CA∣B​]12​=0⟺[(PA​)−1]12​=0. We use the well-known formula for the inverse of a two-by-two matrix to obtain \begin{align} (P_A)^{-1} &= \begin{bmatrix} P_{ii} & P_{ij} \newline P_{ji} & P_{jj} \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{P_{ii}P_{jj}- P_{ij}^2} \begin{bmatrix} P_{jj} & -P_{ji} \newline -P_{ij} & P_{ii}\end{bmatrix}. \end{align} Notice that the off-diagonal entries of PAP_APA​ and (PA)−1(P_A)^{-1}(PA​)−1 are the same, up to a minus sign. This means Cov[xi,xj∣xB]=[CA∣B]12=0  ⟺  Pij=0, \text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B] = [C_{A|B}]_{12} = 0 \iff P_{ij} = 0, Cov[xi​,xj​∣xB​]=[CA∣B​]12​=0⟺Pij​=0, so the result is proved. The fact that conditional uncorrelatedness implies conditional independence follows from the fact that xA∣xBx_A|x_BxA​∣xB​ is Gaussian. ■\qquad \blacksquare■

The above result interprets the zero values of off-diagonal elements of the precision matrix. Later in this post we will revisit the precision, and see that non-zero values can be interpreted through the lens of partial correlation. An interpretation of the magnitude of the diagonal elements is more straightforward, and is given in the below result.

Diagonal Entries of Precision.
The diagonal entry PiiP_{ii}Pii​ of the precision gives the reciprocal of the variance of xix_ixi​, conditional on all other variables; that is, Pii=Var[xi∣x∼i]−1(12) P_{ii} = \text{Var}[x_i|x_{\sim i}]^{-1} \tag{12} Pii​=Var[xi​∣x∼i​]−1(12)

Proof. We know from (9) that CA∣B=(PA)−1C_{A|B} = (P_A)^{-1}CA∣B​=(PA​)−1. Let A:={i}A := \{i\}A:={i} and B:={1,…,n}∖{i}B := \{1, \dots, n\} \setminus \{i\}B:={1,…,n}∖{i}. It follows that Var[xi∣x∼i]=CA∣B=(PA)−1=Pii−1.■ \text{Var}[x_i|x_{\sim i}] = C_{A|B} = (P_A)^{-1} = P_{ii}^{-1}. \qquad \qquad \blacksquare Var[xi​∣x∼i​]=CA∣B​=(PA​)−1=Pii−1​.■

Notions of Linear Conditional Dependence

In this section, we introduce two analogs of the correlation coefficient that quantify the linear dependence between two variables, conditional on another set of variables. We show that if all random variables are jointly Gaussian, then the two notions coincide.

Conditional Correlation

We start by defining conditional correlation, which is nothing more than the typical notion of correlation but defined with respect to a conditional probability measure. We give the definition with respect to our current setup, but of course the notion can be generalized.

Definition: conditional correlation.
For a pair of indices {i,j}\{i,j\}{i,j} and its complement B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}B := \{1, \dots, n\} \setminus \{i,j\}B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}, we define the conditional covariance between xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​, given xBx_BxB​, as Cov[xi,xj∣xB]:=EB[(xi−EB[xi])(xj−EB[xj])],(13) \text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B] := \mathbb{E}^B\left[(x_i-\mathbb{E}^B[x_i])(x_j-\mathbb{E}^B[x_j]) \right], \tag{13} Cov[xi​,xj​∣xB​]:=EB[(xi​−EB[xi​])(xj​−EB[xj​])],(13) where we denote EB[⋅]:=E[⋅∣xB]\mathbb{E}^B[\cdot] := \mathbb{E}[\cdot|x_B]EB[⋅]:=E[⋅∣xB​]. The conditional correlation is then defined as usual by normalizing the covariance (13): Cor[xi,xj∣xB]:=Cov[xi,xj∣xB]Var[xi∣xB]Var[xj∣xB].(14) \text{Cor}[x_i,x_j|x_B] := \frac{\text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B]}{\sqrt{\text{Var}[x_i|x_B]\text{Var}[x_j|x_B]}}. \tag{14} Cor[xi​,xj​∣xB​]:=Var[xi​∣xB​]Var[xj​∣xB​]​Cov[xi​,xj​∣xB​]​.(14)

The conditional correlation is simply a correlation where all expectations involved are conditional on xBx_BxB​. It is sometimes also denoted as ρij∣B:=Cor[xi,xj∣xB]\rho_{ij|B} := \text{Cor}[x_i,x_j|x_B]ρij∣B​:=Cor[xi​,xj​∣xB​].

Partial correlation

We now consider an alternative notion of conditional linear dependence that is defined with respect to underlying linear regression models. For generality, we provide a definition that quantifies dependence between sets of variables xA1x_{A_1}xA1​​ and xA2x_{A_2}xA2​​, after removing the confounding effect of a third set xBx_{B}xB​. However, our primary interest will be in the special case A1={i}A_1 = \{i\}A1​={i} and A2={j}A_2 = \{j\}A2​={j}, which aligns with the conditional correlation definition given above.

Definition: partial correlation.
For a set of random variables x1,…,xnx_1, \dots, x_nx1​,…,xn​, let A1,A2⊂{1,…,n}A_1,A_2 \subset \{1, \dots, n\}A1​,A2​⊂{1,…,n} be index sets and BBB a third index set disjoint from the other two. Define the linear regression coefficients \begin{align} \alpha_{A_1}^\star, \beta_{A_1}^\star &:= \text{argmin}_{\alpha,\beta} \mathbb{E}\lVert x_{A_1} - \alpha + \beta_{A_1}^\top x_B)\rVert^2 \tag{15} \newline \alpha_{A_2}^\star, \beta_{A_2}^\star &:= \text{argmin}_{\alpha,\beta} \mathbb{E} \lVert x_{A_2} - (\alpha + \beta_{A_2}^\top x_B)\rVert^2, \end{align} and associated residuals \begin{align} e_{A_1} &:= x_{A_1} - (\alpha_{A_1}^\star + [\beta_{A_1}^\star)^\top x_B] \tag{16} \newline e_{A_2} &:= x_{A_2} - (\alpha_{A_2}^\star + [\beta_{A_2}^\star)^\top x_B]. \end{align} The partial correlation coefficient between xA1x_{A_1}xA1​​ and xA2x_{A_2}xA2​​ given xBx_BxB​ is defined as ρA1A2⋅B:=Cor[eA1,eA2].(17) \rho_{A_{1}A_{2} \cdot B} := \text{Cor}[e_{A_1}, e_{A_2}]. \tag{17} ρA1​A2​⋅B​:=Cor[eA1​​,eA2​​].(17)

The intuition here is that the residuals from the regressions contain variation that is unexplained by xBx_BxB​, so that ρA1A2⋅B\rho_{A_{1}A_{2} \cdot B}ρA1​A2​⋅B​ quantifies the linear dependence between xA1x_{A_1}xA1​​ and xA2x_{A_2}xA2​​ after removing the effect of xBx_BxB​. We emphasize the importance of the word “linear” here, as linearity plays a role in two different ways in the above definition. Recall that the typical correlation coefficient measures linear dependence, so the statement in (17) is a measure of linear dependence between the residuals. Moreover, the residuals themselves are defined via linear regressions, and hence the sense in which the effect of xBx_BxB​ is “removed” also relies on linearity assumptions. Note also that we are allowing xA1x_{A_1}xA1​​ and xA2x_{A_2}xA2​​ to be sets of variables, so the linear regressions considered above are multi-output regressions, which can essentially be thought of as a set of independent univariate regressions, since the loss function simply sums the error across the outputs. Thus, in general, the α\alphaαs and β\betaβs are vectors and matrices, respectively.

Equivalence for Gaussian Distributions

We now introduce the additional assumption that x1,…xnx_1, \dots x_nx1​,…xn​ are jointly Gaussian and show that in this setting the definitions of conditional and partial correlation are equivalent. For more detailed discussion on these connections, see (Baba et al., 2004) and (Lawrance, 1976).

Conditional and Partial Correlation for Gaussians.
Suppose that x1,…,xnx_1, \dots, x_nx1​,…,xn​ are jointly Gaussian, with positive definite covariance CCC. For a pair of indices {i,j}\{i,j\}{i,j} and its complement B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}B := \{1, \dots, n\} \setminus \{i,j\}B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}, we have ρij⋅B=Cor[xi,xj∣xB].(18) \rho_{ij \cdot B} = \text{Cor}[x_i,x_j|x_B]. \tag{18} ρij⋅B​=Cor[xi​,xj​∣xB​].(18) That is, under joint Gaussianity the notions of conditional and partial correlation coincide.

Proof. The result will be proved by establishing that Cov[ei,ej]=Cov[xi,xj∣xB](19) \text{Cov}[e_i,e_j] = \text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B] \tag{19} Cov[ei​,ej​]=Cov[xi​,xj​∣xB​](19) for any iii and jjj (possibly equal), where eie_iei​ and eje_jej​ are the residual random variables defined in (16) with A1:={i}A_1 := \{i\}A1​:={i} and A2:={j}A_2 := \{j\}A2​:={j}. The i=ji=ji=j case establishes the equality of the variances, meaning that the correlations will also be equal. To this end, we start by noting that the righthand side in (19) is given by the relevant entry of the matrix CA∣B=CA−CABCB−1CBA. C_{A|B} = C_A - C_{AB}C_B^{-1}C_{BA}. CA∣B​=CA​−CAB​CB−1​CBA​. where A:={i,j}A := \{i,j\}A:={i,j}. Recall that CA∣BC_{A|B}CA∣B​ is defined in (4). By extracting the relevant entry of CA∣BC_{A|B}CA∣B​ we have Cov[xi,xj∣xB]=Cij−CiBCB−1CBj.(20) \text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B] = C_{ij} - C_{iB}C_B^{-1}C_{Bj}. \tag{20} Cov[xi​,xj​∣xB​]=Cij​−CiB​CB−1​CBj​.(20) We now show that Cov[ei,ej]\text{Cov}[e_i,e_j]Cov[ei​,ej​] reduces to (20). We recall that the conditional expectation for a square-integrable random variable is given by the projection E[xi∣xB]=argming∥xi−g(xB)∥2,(21) \mathbb{E}[x_i|x_B] = \text{argmin}_{g} \lVert x_i - g(x_B)\rVert^2, \tag{21} E[xi​∣xB​]=argming​∥xi​−g(xB​)∥2,(21) where the minimum is considered over all xBx_BxB​-measurable functions ggg. In our present Gaussian setting, this is solved by E[xi∣xB]=E[xi]+⟨ki,xB−E[xB]⟩,(22) \mathbb{E}[x_i|x_B] = \mathbb{E}[x_i] + \langle k_i, x_B-\mathbb{E}[x_B]\rangle, \tag{22} E[xi​∣xB​]=E[xi​]+⟨ki​,xB​−E[xB​]⟩,(22) where ki=Cov[xB]−1Cov[xB,xi]=CB−1CiBk_i = \text{Cov}[x_B]^{-1} \text{Cov}[x_B,x_i] = C_B^{-1}C_{iB}ki​=Cov[xB​]−1Cov[xB​,xi​]=CB−1​CiB​. See this post for the derivation of (22). The important thing to notice is that (22) is a linear function of xBx_BxB​, which means that it solves the linear regression problem (15); i.e., αA1⋆+(βA1⋆)⊤xB=E[xi∣xB]\alpha^{\star}_{A_1} + (\beta^{\star}_{A_1})^\top x_B = \mathbb{E}[x_i|x_B]αA1​⋆​+(βA1​⋆​)⊤xB​=E[xi​∣xB​]. Thus, ei=xi−E[xi∣xB]=xi−E[xi]−⟨ki,xB−E[xB]⟩.(23) e_i = x_i - \mathbb{E}[x_i|x_B] = x_i - \mathbb{E}[x_i] - \langle k_i, x_B-\mathbb{E}[x_B]\rangle. \tag{23} ei​=xi​−E[xi​∣xB​]=xi​−E[xi​]−⟨ki​,xB​−E[xB​]⟩.(23) and similarly for eje_jej​. Notice that the constants E[xi]\mathbb{E}[x_i]E[xi​] and E[xB]\mathbb{E}[x_B]E[xB​] will be dropped when taking covariances, so it suffices to treat these as zero. We thus have \begin{align} \text{Cov}[e_i,e_j] &= \text{Cov}[x_i-\langle k_i, x_B\rangle,x_j-\langle k_j, x_B\rangle] \newline &= C_{ij} + k_i^\top C_B k_j - C_{iB}k_j - k_i^\top k_j - k_i^\top C_{Bj} \newline &= C_{ij} + C_{iB}C_B^{-1}C_B C_B^{-1}C_{Bj} - 2C_{iB}C_B^{-1}C_{Bj} \newline &= C_{ij} - C_{iB}C_B^{-1}C_{Bj}. \end{align} We see that the final expression agrees with (20), so the result is proved. ■\qquad \blacksquare■

Precision Matrix and Partial Correlation

Having defined partial and conditional correlation, we now return to the question of interpreting the off-diagonal elements of a Gaussian precision matrix. Throughout this section we assume that x1,…,xnx_1, \dots, x_nx1​,…,xn​ are jointly Gaussian with positive definite covariance CCC and precision matrix PPP. The following definition normalizes the precision matrix, analogous to the way a covariance matrix is normalized to produce a correlation matrix.

Normalized Precision.
Define the normalized precision Pˉ\bar{P}Pˉ as the matrix with elements Pˉij:=PijPiiPjj.(24) \bar{P}_{ij} := \frac{P_{ij}}{\sqrt{P_{ii}P_{jj}}}. \tag{24} Pˉij​:=Pii​Pjj​​Pij​​.(24)

We are now ready to establish the connection between the (normalized) precision and the notions of conditional and partial correlation. Note that the diagonal elements of Pˉ\bar{P}Pˉ satisfy Pˉii=1\bar{P}_{ii}=1Pˉii​=1. The following result interprets the off-diagonal elements.

Off-Diagonal Entries of Precision.
Assume that x1,…,xnx_1, \dots, x_nx1​,…,xn​ are jointly Gaussian with normalized precision matrix Pˉ\bar{P}Pˉ. Let {i,j}\{i,j\}{i,j} be a pair of distinct indices and B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j}B := \{1,\dots,n\} \setminus \{i,j\}B:={1,…,n}∖{i,j} its complement. Then Pˉij=−ρij⋅B=−Cor[xi,xj∣xB].(25) \bar{P}_{ij} = -\rho_{ij\cdot B} = -\text{Cor}[x_i,x_j|x_B]. \tag{25} Pˉij​=−ρij⋅B​=−Cor[xi​,xj​∣xB​].(25) In words, the off-diagonal entry Pˉij\bar{P}_{ij}Pˉij​ is equal to the negated partial correlation between xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​ given all other variables. It is likewise equal to the negated conditional correlation.

Proof. Let A:={i,j}A := \{i,j\}A:={i,j}. Recall from (9) that \begin{align} C_{A|B} &= (P_A)^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} P_{ii} & P_{ij} \newline P_{ji} & P_{jj} \end{bmatrix}^{-1} = \gamma \begin{bmatrix} P_{jj} & -P_{ij} \newline -P_{ji} & P_{ii} \end{bmatrix}, \tag{26} \end{align} with γ:=(PiiPjj−Pij2)−1\gamma := (P_{ii}P_{jj}-P^2_{ij})^{-1}γ:=(Pii​Pjj​−Pij2​)−1. We have again used the expression for the inverse of a two-by-two matrix. The equality in (26) gives \begin{align} \text{Var}[x_i|x_B] &= \gamma P_{jj} \newline \text{Var}[x_j|x_B] &= \gamma P_{ii} \newline \text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B] &= -\gamma P_{ij}. \end{align} We thus have Pˉij=PijPiiPjj=−Cov[xi,xj∣xB]Var[xi∣xB]Var[xj∣xB]=−Cor[xi,xj∣xB]. \bar{P}_{ij} = \frac{P_{ij}}{\sqrt{P_{ii}P_{jj}}} = -\frac{\text{Cov}[x_i,x_j|x_B]}{\sqrt{\text{Var}[x_i|x_B]\text{Var}[x_j|x_B]}} = -\text{Cor}[x_i,x_j|x_B]. Pˉij​=Pii​Pjj​​Pij​​=−Var[xi​∣xB​]Var[xj​∣xB​]​Cov[xi​,xj​∣xB​]​=−Cor[xi​,xj​∣xB​]. This establishes the relationship between the precision elements and conditional correlation. Under the Gaussian assumption, the equivalence with the partial correlation follows from (18). ■\qquad \blacksquare■

In addition to (Lauritzen, 2019), (Baba et al., 2004), and (Lawrance, 1976), here is a list of some other resources that cover similar topics.

entry.title: Gaussian Kernel Hyperparameters
entry.content:
In this post we discuss the interpretation of the hyperparameters defining a Gaussian covariance function. We then consider some practical considerations to keep in mind when learning the values of these parameters. In particular, we focus on setting bounds and initialization values to avoid common pathologies in hyperparameter optimization. The typical application is hyperparameter estimation for Gaussian process models. It is important to emphasize that ideally one would define informative priors on hyperparameters and cast hyperparameter optimization within a Bayesian inferential framework. Even if one is only optimizing hyperparameters, prior distributions offer a principled means of regularizing the optimization problem. In this post, we focus only on bound constraints for hyperparameters, which can be thought of equivalently as uniform priors. In addition, we consider the setting where little prior knowledge is available, so that they main purpose of the bounds is to avoid pathological behavior in the optimization. We discuss heuristic methods for empirically deriving reasonable default bounds based on the training data. Deriving the bounds from the training data also implies that the process can be automated, which may be useful in certain contexts. In general, I would typically recommend considering priors other than uniform distributions. However, I think this is still a useful exercise to think through. Moreover, many of the more classically-oriented Gaussian process packages (e.g., kergp and hetGP in R) only offer hyperparameter regularization via bound constraints. For a discussion on non-uniform priors and full Bayesian inference for Gaussian process hyperparameters, see Michael Betencourt’s excellent posts here and here.

The Gaussian covariance function

One-Dimensional Input Space

entry.summary: In this post we discuss the interpretation of the hyperparameters defining a Gaussian covariance function. We then consider some practical considerations to keep in mind when learning the values of these parameters. In particular, we focus on setting bounds and initialization values to avoid common pathologies in hyperparameter optimization. The typical application is hyperparameter estimation for Gaussian process models. It is important to emphasize that ideally one would define informative priors on hyperparameters and cast hyperparameter optimization within a Bayesian inferential framework. Even if one is only optimizing hyperparameters, prior distributions offer a principled means of regularizing the optimization problem. In this post, we focus only on bound constraints for hyperparameters, which can be thought of equivalently as uniform priors. In addition, we consider the setting where little prior knowledge is available, so that they main purpose of the bounds is to avoid pathological behavior in the optimization. We discuss heuristic methods for empirically deriving reasonable default bounds based on the training data. Deriving the bounds from the training data also implies that the process can be automated, which may be useful in certain contexts. In general, I would typically recommend considering priors other than uniform distributions. However, I think this is still a useful exercise to think through. Moreover, many of the more classically-oriented Gaussian process packages (e.g., kergp and hetGP in R) only offer hyperparameter regularization via bound constraints. For a discussion on non-uniform priors and full Bayesian inference for Gaussian process hyperparameters, see Michael Betencourt’s excellent posts here and here.

entry.content:
In this post we consider the Cholesky decomposition of the covariance matrix of a Gaussian distribution. The eigendecomposition of covariance matrices gives rise to the well-known method of principal components analysis. The Cholesky decomposition is not as widely discussed in this context, but also has a variety of useful statistical applications.

Setup and Background

The Cholesky Decomposition

The Cholesky decomposition of a positive definite matrix CCC is the unique factorization of the form C=LL⊤,(1) C = LL^\top, \tag{1} C=LL⊤,(1) where LLL is a lower-triangular matrix with positive diagonal elements (note that constraining the diagonal to be positive is required for uniqueness). A positive definite matrix can also be uniquely decomposed as C=LDL⊤,(2) C = LDL^\top, \tag{2} C=LDL⊤,(2) where LLL is lower-triangular with ones on the diagonal, and DDD is a diagonal matrix with positive entries on the diagonal. We will refer to this as the modified Cholesky decomposition, but it is also often called the LDL decomposition. Given the modified Cholesky decomposition C=L~DL~⊤C = \tilde{L}D\tilde{L}^\topC=L~DL~⊤, we can form (1) by setting L:=L~D1/2L := \tilde{L}D^{1/2}L:=L~D1/2. We refer to both L~\tilde{L}L~ and LLL as the lower Cholesky factor of CCC; which we are referring to will be clear from context. LLL is guaranteed to be invertible, and L−1L^{-1}L−1 is itself a lower-triangular matrix. Finally, note that we could also consider decompositions of the form C=UDU⊤,(3) C = UDU^\top, \tag{3} C=UDU⊤,(3) where UUU is upper triangular. This “reversed” Cholesky decomposition is not as common, but will show up at one point in this post.

Statistical Setup

Throughout this post we consider a random vector x:=(x(1),…,x(p))⊤∈Rp,(4) x := \left(x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(p)} \right)^\top \in \mathbb{R}^p, \tag{4} x:=(x(1),…,x(p))⊤∈Rp,(4) with positive definite covariance C:=Cov[x]C := \text{Cov}[x]C:=Cov[x]. We will often assume that xxx is Gaussian, but this assumption is not required for some of the results discussed below. We focus on the (modified) Cholesky decomposition C=LDL⊤C = LDL^\topC=LDL⊤, letting L={ℓij}L = \{\ell_{ij}\}L={ℓij​} denote the entries of the lower Cholesky factor. For the modified decomposition, we write D:=diag(d1,…,dp)D := \text{diag}(d_1, \dots, d_p)D:=diag(d1​,…,dp​), where each dj>0d_j > 0dj​>0.

Let C=LDL⊤C = LDL^\topC=LDL⊤ and define the random variable ϵ:=L−1x,(5) \epsilon := L^{-1}x, \tag{5} ϵ:=L−1x,(5) which satisfies Cov[ϵ]=L−1CL−⊤=L−1LDL⊤L−⊤=D.(6) \text{Cov}[\epsilon] = L^{-1}CL^{-\top} = L^{-1}LDL^\top L^{-\top} = D. \tag{6} Cov[ϵ]=L−1CL−⊤=L−1LDL⊤L−⊤=D.(6) Thus, the map x↦L−1xx \mapsto L^{-1}xx↦L−1x outputs a “decorrelated” random vector. The inverse map ϵ↦Lϵ\epsilon \mapsto L\epsilonϵ↦Lϵ “re-correlates” ϵ\epsilonϵ, producing a random vector with covariance CCC. If we add on the assumption that xxx is Gaussian, then ϵ\epsilonϵ is a Gaussian vector with independent entries. The transformation LϵL\epsilonLϵ is the typical method used in simulating draws from a correlated Gaussian vector. Note that if we instead considered the standard Cholesky factorization C=LL⊤C = LL^\topC=LL⊤ with ϵ\epsilonϵ still defined as in (5), then Cov[ϵ]=I\text{Cov}[\epsilon] = ICov[ϵ]=I.

Conditional Variances and Covariances

We start by demonstrating how the (modified) Cholesky decomposition encodes information related to conditional variances and covariances between the x(j)x^{(j)}x(j). The below result considers conditional variances, and provides an interpretation of the diagonal entries of DDD in the Gaussian setting.

Proposition (conditional variances).
Let x∼N(m,C)x \sim \mathcal{N}(m,C)x∼N(m,C), with C=Cov[x]C = \text{Cov}[x]C=Cov[x] positive definite. Set ϵ:=L−1x\epsilon := L^{-1}xϵ:=L−1x, where C=LDL⊤C = LDL^\topC=LDL⊤. Then Var[x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=dj,j=1,…,p(7) \text{Var}[x^{(j)}|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}] = d_j, \qquad j = 1, \dots, p \tag{7} Var[x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=dj​,j=1,…,p(7) where the j=1j=1j=1 case is interpreted as the unconditional variance Var[x(1)]\text{Var}[x^{(1)}]Var[x(1)]. If we instead define LLL by C=LL⊤C = LL^\topC=LL⊤, then Var[x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=ℓjj2,j=1,…,p.(8) \text{Var}[x^{(j)}|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}] = \ell^2_{jj}, \qquad j = 1, \dots, p. \tag{8} Var[x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=ℓjj2​,j=1,…,p.(8)

Proof. From the definition x=Lϵx = L\epsilonx=Lϵ and the fact that LLL is lower triangular, we have x(j)=∑k=1jℓjkϵ(k).(9) x^{(j)} = \sum_{k=1}^{j} \ell_{jk} \epsilon^{(k)}. \tag{9} x(j)=k=1∑j​ℓjk​ϵ(k).(9) Thus,

\begin{align} \text{Var}[x^{(j)}|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}] = \text{Var}\left[\sum_{k=1}^{j} \ell_{jk} \epsilon^{(k)} \bigg|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}\right] &= \text{Var}\left[\sum_{k=1}^{j} \ell_{jk} \epsilon^{(k)} \bigg|\epsilon^{(1)}, \dots, \epsilon^{(j-1)}\right] \newline &= \text{Var}\left[\ell_{jj} \epsilon^{(j)}|\epsilon^{(1)}, \dots, \epsilon^{(j-1)}\right] \newline &= \text{Var}\left[\ell_{jj} \epsilon^{(j)}\right] \newline &= \ell^2_{jj} \text{Var}[\epsilon^{(j)}]. \tag{10} \end{align}

The first equality follows from the fact that xxx is an invertible transformation of ϵ\epsilonϵ, while the fourth uses the fact that the ϵ(j)\epsilon^{(j)}ϵ(j) are independent (owing to the Gaussian assumption). In the modified Cholesky case, (10) simplifies to ℓjj2Var[ϵ(j)]=1×dj=dj\ell^2_{jj} \text{Var}[\epsilon^{(j)}] = 1 \times d_j = d_jℓjj2​Var[ϵ(j)]=1×dj​=dj​. For standard Cholesky, it becomes ℓjj2Var[ϵ(j)]=ℓjj2⋅1=ℓjj2\ell^2_{jj} \text{Var}[\epsilon^{(j)}] = \ell^2_{jj} \cdot 1 = \ell^2_{jj}ℓjj2​Var[ϵ(j)]=ℓjj2​⋅1=ℓjj2​. ■\qquad \blacksquare■

Thus, the diagonal entries of DDD give the variances of the x(j)x^{(j)}x(j), conditional on all preceding entries in the vector. Clearly, the interpretation depends on the ordering of the entries, a fact that will be true for many results that rely on the Cholesky decomposition.

We can generalize the above result to consider conditional covariances instead of variances, which yields an interpretation of the off-diagonal elements of LLL.

Proposition (conditional covariances).
Let x∼N(m,C)x \sim \mathcal{N}(m,C)x∼N(m,C), with C=Cov[x]C = \text{Cov}[x]C=Cov[x] positive definite. Set ϵ:=L−1x\epsilon := L^{-1}xϵ:=L−1x, where C=LDL⊤C = LDL^\topC=LDL⊤. Then for i>ji > ji>j, Cov[x(i),x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=ℓijdj,j=1,…,p−1(11) \text{Cov}[x^{(i)}, x^{(j)}|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}] = \ell_{ij}d_j, \qquad j = 1, \dots, p-1 \tag{11} Cov[x(i),x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=ℓij​dj​,j=1,…,p−1(11) where the j=1j=1j=1 case is interpreted as the unconditional covariance Cov[x(i),x(1)]\text{Cov}[x^{(i)},x^{(1)}]Cov[x(i),x(1)]. If we instead define LLL by C=LL⊤C = LL^\topC=LL⊤, then Cov[x(i),x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=ℓijℓjj,j=1,…,p−1.(12) \text{Cov}[x^{(i)}, x^{(j)}|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}] = \ell_{ij}\ell_{jj}, \qquad j = 1, \dots, p-1. \tag{12} Cov[x(i),x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=ℓij​ℓjj​,j=1,…,p−1.(12) In particular, in either case it holds that ℓij=0  ⟺  Cov[x(i),x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=0  ⟺  x(i)⊥x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1).(13) \ell_{ij}=0 \iff \text{Cov}[x^{(i)}, x^{(j)}|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}] = 0 \iff x^{(i)} \perp x^{(j)} | x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}. \tag{13} ℓij​=0⟺Cov[x(i),x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1)]=0⟺x(i)⊥x(j)∣x(1),…,x(j−1).(13)

Proof. The proof proceeds similarly to the conditional variance case. We have \begin{align} \text{Cov}[x^{(i)}, x^{(j)}|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}] &= \text{Cov}\left[\sum_{k=1}^{i} \ell_{ik} \epsilon^{(k)}, \sum_{k=1}^{j} \ell_{jk} \epsilon^{(k)} \bigg|x^{(1)}, \dots, x^{(j-1)}\right] \newline &= \text{Cov}\left[\sum_{k=1}^{i} \ell_{ik} \epsilon^{(k)}, \sum_{k=1}^{j} \ell_{jk} \epsilon^{(k)} \bigg|\epsilon^{(1)}, \dots, \epsilon^{(j-1)}\right] \newline &= \text{Cov}\left[\sum_{k=j}^{i} \ell_{ik} \epsilon^{(k)}, \ell_{jj} \epsilon^{(j)} \bigg|\epsilon^{(1)}, \dots, \epsilon^{(j-1)}\right] \newline &= \sum_{k=j}^{i} \ell_{ik}\ell_{jj} \text{Cov}\left[\epsilon^{(k)}, \epsilon^{(j)}|\epsilon^{(1)}, \dots, \epsilon^{(j-1)}\right] \newline &= \sum_{k=j}^{i} \ell_{ik}\ell_{jj} \text{Cov}\left[\epsilon^{(k)}, \epsilon^{(j)}\right] \newline &= \ell_{ij}\ell_{jj} \text{Var}\left[\epsilon^{(j)}\right] \end{align} The penultimate step uses the fact that the ϵ(j)\epsilon^{(j)}ϵ(j) are conditionally uncorrelated, owing to the fact that the ϵ(j)\epsilon^{(j)}ϵ(j) are jointly Gaussian and independent. The final step also uses the fact that the ϵ(j)\epsilon^{(j)}ϵ(j) are uncorrelated, and hence all terms where k≠jk \neq jk​=j vanish. For C=LDL⊤C = LDL^\topC=LDL⊤ the final expression simplifies to ℓijℓjjVar[ϵ(j)]=ℓij⋅1⋅dj=ℓijdj\ell_{ij}\ell_{jj} \text{Var}\left[\epsilon^{(j)}\right] = \ell_{ij} \cdot 1 \cdot d_j = \ell_{ij}d_jℓij​ℓjj​Var[ϵ(j)]=ℓij​⋅1⋅dj​=ℓij​dj​. For C=LL⊤C = LL^\topC=LL⊤ it becomes ℓijℓjj⋅1=ℓijℓjj\ell_{ij}\ell_{jj} \cdot 1 = \ell_{ij}\ell_{jj}ℓij​ℓjj​⋅1=ℓij​ℓjj​. The first implication in (13) follows immediately from (11) and (12). The second implication follows from the fact that xxx is Gaussian, and hence the conditional uncorrelatedness implies conditional independence. ■\blacksquare■

We thus find that the Cholesky decomposition of a Gaussian covariance is closely linked to the ordered conditional dependence structure of xxx. The factorization encodes conditional covariances, where the conditioning is with respect to all preceding variables; reordering the entries of xxx may yield drastically different insights. The connection between sparsity in the Cholesky factor and conditional independence can be leveraged in the design of statistical models and algorithms. For an example, see the paper (Jurek & Katzfuss, 2021).

A Regression Interpretation

In this section, we summarize a least squares regression interpretation of the modified Cholesky decomposition C=LDL⊤C = LDL^\topC=LDL⊤. The result is similar in spirit to (7), as we will consider a sequence of regressions that condition on previous entries of xxx. The ideas discussed here come primarily from from (Rothman et al., 2010).

Sequence of Least Squares Problems

We start by recursively defining a sequence of least squares problems, which we then link to the factorization C=LDL⊤C = LDL^\topC=LDL⊤.

Sequential Least Squares.
Let x∼N(0,C)x \sim \mathcal{N}(0,C)x∼N(0,C), with C=Cov[x]C = \text{Cov}[x]C=Cov[x] positive definite. We recursively define the entries of ϵ:=(ϵ(1),…,ϵ(p))\epsilon := (\epsilon^{(1)}, \dots, \epsilon^{(p)})ϵ:=(ϵ(1),…,ϵ(p)) as follows:

1. Set ϵ(1):=x(1)\epsilon^{(1)} := x^{(1)}ϵ(1):=x(1).
2. For j=2,…,pj = 2, \dots, pj=2,…,p define the regression coefficient β(j)∈Rj−1\beta^{(j)} \in \R^{j-1}β(j)∈Rj−1 by β(j):=argminβE∣x(j)−∑k=1j−1βkϵ(k)∣2(14) \beta^{(j)} := \text{argmin}_{\beta} \mathbb{E}\left\lvert x^{(j)} - \sum_{k=1}^{j-1} \beta_k \epsilon^{(k)} \right\rvert^2 \tag{14} β(j):=argminβ​E∣∣∣∣∣∣​x(j)−k=1∑j−1​βk​ϵ(k)∣∣∣∣∣∣​2(14) and set ϵ(j):=x(j)−∑k=1j−1βk(j)ϵ(k).(15) \epsilon^{(j)} := x^{(j)} - \sum_{k=1}^{j-1} \beta_k^{(j)} \epsilon^{(k)}. \tag{15} ϵ(j):=x(j)−k=1∑j−1​βk(j)​ϵ(k).(15)

In words, ϵ(j)\epsilon^{(j)}ϵ(j) is the residual of the least squares regression of the response x(j)x^{(j)}x(j) on the explanatory variables ϵ(1),…,ϵ(j−1)\epsilon^{(1)}, \dots, \epsilon^{(j-1)}ϵ(1),…,ϵ(j−1), and β(j)\beta^{(j)}β(j) is the coefficient vector. Take note that we are regressing on the residuals from the previous regressions, rather than the x(j)x^{(j)}x(j) themselves. We assume for simplicity that xxx is mean zero to avoid having to deal with an intercept term; for non mean zero variables, we can start by subtracting off their mean and then apply the same procedure. Note also that the zero mean assumption implies that E[ϵ]=0\mathbb{E}[\epsilon] = 0E[ϵ]=0; this follows from ϵ(1)=x(1)\epsilon^{(1)} = x^{(1)}ϵ(1)=x(1) along with the recursion (15).

Our goal is now to connect this algorithm to the modified Cholesky decomposition of CCC. In particular, we will show that the ϵ\epsilonϵ defined by the regression residuals is precisely the ϵ\epsilonϵ defined in (5), which arises from the modified Cholesky decomposition. To start, note that if we rearrange (15) as x(j):=ϵ(j)+∑k=1j−1β(k)ϵ(k),(16) x^{(j)} := \epsilon^{(j)} + \sum_{k=1}^{j-1} \beta^{(k)} \epsilon^{(k)}, \tag{16} x(j):=ϵ(j)+k=1∑j−1​β(k)ϵ(k),(16) then we see the vectors ϵ\epsilonϵ and xxx are related as x=Lϵ,(17) x = L\epsilon, \tag{17} x=Lϵ,(17) where \begin{align} L &:= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \newline \beta^{(2)}_1 & 1 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \newline \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \cdots & 0 \newline \beta^{(p)}_1 & \beta^{(p)}_2 & \cdots & \cdots & 1\end{bmatrix}. \tag{18} \end{align} That is, we have defined LLL to be the lower triangular matrix with jthj^{\text{th}}jth row set to (β(j),1)(\beta^{(j)}, 1)(β(j),1), the jthj^{\text{th}}jth coefficient vector with a 111 appended to the end. We immediately have that LLL is invertible, as it is a triangular matrix with non-zero entries on the diagonal. We also have C=Cov[x]=Cov[Lϵ]=LCov[ϵ]L⊤.(19) C = \text{Cov}[x] = \text{Cov}[L\epsilon] = L \text{Cov}[\epsilon] L^{\top}. \tag{19} C=Cov[x]=Cov[Lϵ]=LCov[ϵ]L⊤.(19) In order to show that (19) actually yields the modified Cholesky factorization, we must establish that Cov[ϵ]\text{Cov}[\epsilon]Cov[ϵ], the residual covariance matrix, is diagonal with positive diagonal entries.

Proposition.
The random vector ϵ\epsilonϵ defined by (12) satisfies ϵ∼N(0,D),(20) \epsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0, D), \tag{20} ϵ∼N(0,D),(20) where DDD is a diagonal matrix with positive entries on the diagonal.

Proof. The result follows immediately upon viewing (14) as a projection in a suitable inner product space, and then applying the Hilbert projection theorem. In particular, note that all of the x(j)x^{(j)}x(j) and ϵ(j)\epsilon^{(j)}ϵ(j) are zero mean, square integrable random variables. We can thus consider the Hilbert space of all such random variables with inner product defined by ⟨ψ,η⟩:=E[ψη]\langle \psi, \eta \rangle := \mathbb{E}[\psi \eta]⟨ψ,η⟩:=E[ψη]. Under this interpretation, we see that (15) can be rewritten as ∑k=1j−1βk(j)ϵ(k)=argminx′∈E(j)∥x−x′∥,(21) \sum_{k=1}^{j-1} \beta_k^{(j)} \epsilon^{(k)} = \text{argmin}_{x^\prime \in \mathcal{E}^{(j)}} \lVert x - x^\prime \rVert, \tag{21} k=1∑j−1​βk(j)​ϵ(k)=argminx′∈E(j)​∥x−x′∥,(21) where E(j)\mathcal{E}^{(j)}E(j) is the subspace spanned by ϵ(1),…,ϵ(j)\epsilon^{(1)}, \dots, \epsilon^{(j)}ϵ(1),…,ϵ(j) and ∥⋅∥\lVert \cdot \rVert∥⋅∥ is the norm induced by ⟨⋅,⋅⟩\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle⟨⋅,⋅⟩. Since ϵ(j)\epsilon^{(j)}ϵ(j) is the residual associated with the projection (21), the Hilbert projection theorem gives the optimality condition ϵ(j)⊥E(j)\epsilon^{(j)} \perp \mathcal{E}^{(j)}ϵ(j)⊥E(j); that is, ⟨ϵ(j),ϵ(k)⟩=E[ϵ(j)ϵ(k)]=Cov[ϵ(j),ϵ(k)]=0,k=1,…,j−1.(22) \langle \epsilon^{(j)}, \epsilon^{(k)} \rangle = \mathbb{E}[\epsilon^{(j)} \epsilon^{(k)}] = \text{Cov}[\epsilon^{(j)}, \epsilon^{(k)}] = 0, \qquad k = 1, \dots, j-1. \tag{22} ⟨ϵ(j),ϵ(k)⟩=E[ϵ(j)ϵ(k)]=Cov[ϵ(j),ϵ(k)]=0,k=1,…,j−1.(22) This implies that all of the residuals are pairwise uncorrelated, and hence D=Cov[ϵ]D = \text{Cov}[\epsilon]D=Cov[ϵ] is diagonal. We know from (17) that x=Lϵx = L\epsilonx=Lϵ; since C=Cov[x]C = \text{Cov}[x]C=Cov[x] is positive definite, then Cov[ϵ]\text{Cov}[\epsilon]Cov[ϵ] must also be positive definite. Thus, the diagonal entries of DDD must be strictly positive. ■\qquad \blacksquare■

Using the recursive regression procedure in (14) and (15), we have constructed ϵ\epsilonϵ and LLL satisfying C=LDL⊤C = LDL^\topC=LDL⊤, where D=Cov[ϵ]D = \text{Cov}[\epsilon]D=Cov[ϵ] is a diagonal matrix with positive diagonal entries, and LLL is lower triangular. By the uniqueness of the modified Cholesky decomposition (noted in the introduction) it follows that we have precisely formed the unique matrices LLL and DDD defining the modified Cholesky decomposition of CCC.

Connection to the Conditional Covariance Perspective

At this point we have two different interpretations of the (modified) Cholesky decomposition of CCC: (i.) the conditional covariance perspective provided in (12); and (ii.) the regression formulation given in (14), (15), and (18). In particular, these results yield interpretations of the entries of LLL. entry.summary: In this post we consider the Cholesky decomposition of the covariance matrix of a Gaussian distribution. The eigendecomposition of covariance matrices gives rise to the well-known method of principal components analysis. The Cholesky decomposition is not as widely discussed in this context, but also has a variety of useful statistical applications.

entry.content:
Consider a typical Bayesian model consisting of a joint data-parameter distribution p(y,θ)p(y,\theta)p(y,θ). The goal is to characterize the posterior distribution π(θ):=p(θ∣y=yobs)\pi(\theta) := p(\theta|y=y_{\text{obs}})π(θ):=p(θ∣y=yobs​), where yobsy_{\text{obs}}yobs​ is the fixed data realization. In this post, we consider the setting where π\piπ may contain many local modes. There are specialty MCMC algorithms (e.g., using tempering approaches) designed to be able to hop between modes, but in general sampling from such distributions is very challenging. An alternative perspective on this problem is to abandon the hope of designing an algorithm that will generate exact posterior samples and instead be content with “exploring” the most important regions of the parameter space. Multiple chains of a standard MCMC algorithm can be run from different initial conditions, with the hope that collectively the chains will identify the dominant modes of the posterior, even though individually each may be stuck in a single mode. This is the perspective taken in (Yao et al., 2022). The authors note the observation that it is often not difficult to achieve good within-chain mixing adapted to a local region of the posterior, even when it is near impossible to achieve such mixing with respect to the whole distribution. In this post, I summarize a few different approaches used in the literature that adopt this perspective. This is certainly not a comprehensive review, and I will likely add to this post if I come across new ideas.

Setup

Consider the typical problem of estimating the expectation of ϕ(θ)\phi(\theta)ϕ(θ), where θ∼π\theta \sim \piθ∼π, for some function ϕ(⋅)\phi(\cdot)ϕ(⋅) (e.g., estimating a posterior mean or variance). This expectation is given by π(ϕ):=E[ϕ(θ)∣y=yobs]=∫ϕ(θ)π(dθ).(1) \pi(\phi) := \mathbb{E}[\phi(\theta)|y=y_{\text{obs}}] = \int \phi(\theta) \pi(d\theta). \tag{1} π(ϕ):=E[ϕ(θ)∣y=yobs​]=∫ϕ(θ)π(dθ).(1) Suppose we run MMM MCMC chains and obtain samples θm:={θm(k)}k=1Km\theta_m := \{\theta_m^{(k)}\}_{k=1}^{K_m}θm​:={θm(k)​}k=1Km​​ for each of the chains m=1,…,Mm = 1, \dots, Mm=1,…,M. Here, KmK_mKm​ is the number of samples from the mthm^{\text{th}}mth chain and θm(k)\theta_m^{(k)}θm(k)​ is the kthk^{\text{th}}kth draw from the mthm^{\text{th}}mth chain. We assume that each set of samples θm\theta_mθm​ is well-mixed with respect to a local region of the posterior, and that any burn-in has already been dropped. We can think of each θm\theta_mθm​ as a summary of one of the dominant modes of the distribution, but of course in reality it may be that we have completely missed some modes or multiple chains end up in the same mode. In any case, the question is now how to use the sets of samples θ1,…,θM\theta_1, \dots, \theta_Mθ1​,…,θM​ to estimate (1). The problem is that even if the chains are well-mixed with respect to each mode, it is not obvious how to estimate the relative weights of the modes.

Some Basic Ideas

Perhaps the simplest approach is to simply weight all of the chains equally; i.e., compute the sample mean for each chain separately and then take an average of all the chain means. The gives the estimator π^(ϕ):=1M∑m=1M1Km∑k=1Kmϕ(θk(m)).(2) \hat{\pi}(\phi) := \frac{1}{M} \sum_{m=1}^{M} \frac{1}{K_m} \sum_{k=1}^{K_m} \phi(\theta_k^{(m)}). \tag{2} π^(ϕ):=M1​m=1∑M​Km​1​k=1∑Km​​ϕ(θk(m)​).(2)

A natural generalization is to introduce weights w1,…,wMw_1, \dots, w_Mw1​,…,wM​ that may differ for each chain, yielding π^(ϕ):=∑m=1MwmKm∑k=1Kmϕ(θk(m)).(3) \hat{\pi}(\phi) := \sum_{m=1}^{M} \frac{w_m}{K_m} \sum_{k=1}^{K_m} \phi(\theta_k^{(m)}). \tag{3} π^(ϕ):=m=1∑M​Km​wm​​k=1∑Km​​ϕ(θk(m)​).(3) Note that (2) is a special case of (3) with wm:=M−1w_m := M^{-1}wm​:=M−1. The question is how to choose these weights. In running the MCMC algorithm, we obtain information about the relative importance of different regions via the evaluation of the posterior density at each iteration. Let’s denote by ℓm:={ℓm(k)}k=1Km\ell_m := \{\ell_m^{(k)}\}_{k=1}^{K_m}ℓm​:={ℓm(k)​}k=1Km​​ and ρm:={ρm(k)}k=1Km\rho_m := \{\rho_m^{(k)}\}_{k=1}^{K_m}ρm​:={ρm(k)​}k=1Km​​ the log-likelihood and log (unnormalized) posterior density evaluations from chain mmm. A natural choice for weights might then be wm∝exp⁡{ℓˉm}w_m \propto \exp\{\bar{\ell}_m\}wm​∝exp{ℓˉm​} or wm∝exp⁡{ρˉm}w_m \propto \exp\{\bar{\rho}_m\}wm​∝exp{ρˉ​m​}, where ℓˉm\bar{\ell}_mℓˉm​ and ρˉm\bar{\rho}_mρˉ​m​ denote the sample means of ℓm\ell_mℓm​ and ρm\rho_mρm​, respectively; i.e., ℓˉm:=1Km∑k=1Kmℓm(k)(4) \bar{\ell}_m := \frac{1}{K_m} \sum_{k=1}^{K_m} \ell_m^{(k)} \tag{4} ℓˉm​:=Km​1​k=1∑Km​​ℓm(k)​(4)

If one of the chains got stuck in a local mode in a negligible region of parameter space, then the log likelihood (or posterior density) evaluations in that region will be very small, so wm≈0w_m \approx 0wm​≈0.

A Simple Heuristic

We now explore a slight generalization of the above idea that was introduced in (Pritchard et al., 2000). The context in the paper is actually quite different; the heuristic is used to select the number of clusters in a clustering model. However, the idea nicely applies to the problem of combining nonmixing MCMC chains. The idea boils down to treating each chain as corresponding to a different “model” and set each weight wmw_mwm​ to an estimate of the corresponding marginal likelihood under that “model”. In reality, the only model here is p(θ,y)p(\theta,y)p(θ,y) and the marginal likelihood is p(yobs):=p(y=yobs)=∫p(y=yobs,θ)π(dθ)(5) p(y_{\text{obs}}) := p(y=y_{\text{obs}}) = \int p(y=y_{\text{obs}}, \theta) \pi(d\theta) \tag{5} p(yobs​):=p(y=yobs​)=∫p(y=yobs​,θ)π(dθ)(5) However, we will think of there being a marginal likelihood p(yobs∣M=m)p(y_{\text{obs}}|\mathcal{M}=m)p(yobs​∣M=m) corresponding to each of the MMM chains. The idea is now to produce an estimate of p(yobs∣M=m)p(y_{\text{obs}}|\mathcal{M}=m)p(yobs​∣M=m) using the log-likelihood evaluations ℓm\ell_mℓm​ and then set the weight wmw_mwm​ to this estimate. Define the log of this quantity as Lm:=log⁡p(yobs∣M=m),(6) \mathcal{L}_m := \log p(y_{\text{obs}}|\mathcal{M}=m), \tag{6} Lm​:=logp(yobs​∣M=m),(6) which we emphasize is random as a function of θ∼π\theta \sim \piθ∼π (see (5)). Assuming the individual chains are well-mixed, we can view ℓm\ell_mℓm​ as a set of (correlated) samples from Lm\mathcal{L}_mLm​. Computing a Monte Carlo estimate of Lm\mathcal{L}_mLm​ and then exponentiating the result would produce wm∝exp⁡{ℓˉm}w_m \propto \exp\{\bar{\ell}_m\}wm​∝exp{ℓˉm​}, the same weight mentioned in the previous section. The paper (Pritchard et al., 2000) considers an alternative heuristic: assume that Lm\mathcal{L}_mLm​ is Gaussian distributed. We estimate the mean ℓˉm\bar{\ell}_mℓˉm​ as in (4), but now also estimate the variance σ^m2:=1Km−1∑k=1Km(ℓm(k)−ℓˉm)2.(7) \hat{\sigma}^2_m := \frac{1}{K_m - 1} \sum_{k=1}^{K_m} \left(\ell^{(k)}_m - \bar{\ell}_m \right)^2. \tag{7} σ^m2​:=Km​−11​k=1∑Km​​(ℓm(k)​−ℓˉm​)2.(7) and approximate the distribution of Lm\mathcal{L}_mLm​ as L^m∼N(ℓˉm,σ^m2).(8) \hat{\mathcal{L}}_m \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\bar{\ell}_m, \hat{\sigma}^2_m\right). \tag{8} L^m​∼N(ℓˉm​,σ^m2​).(8) The chain weights are then set to wm∝E[exp⁡{L^m}]=exp⁡{ℓˉm+12σ^m2},(9) w_m \propto \mathbb{E}\left[\exp\left\{\hat{\mathcal{L}}_m\right\}\right] = \exp\left\{\bar{\ell}_m + \frac{1}{2}\hat{\sigma}^2_m \right\}, \tag{9} wm​∝E[exp{L^m​}]=exp{ℓˉm​+21​σ^m2​},(9) where we have used the expression for the expectation of a log-normal. As opposed to just using ℓˉm\bar{\ell}_mℓˉm​, the weight (9) also takes into account the variability of the samples in each chain. In a sense, ℓˉm\bar{\ell}_mℓˉm​ captures the average height of the mode, while σ^m2\hat{\sigma}^2_mσ^m2​ captures some notion of its width. This is completely heuristic, but at the very least it seems reasonable to take into account both the height of the modes, as well as the volume they occupy in parameter space, in estimating their relative importance.

entry.title: Regularized Least Squares with Singular Prior

link.title: Regularized Least Squares with Singular Prior

entry.content:
Setup

Recall the L2L^2L2 regularized least squares problem (i.e., ridge regression),

\begin{align} u_{\star} &:= \text{argmin}_{u \in \mathbb{R}^d} J(u) \tag{1} \newline J(u) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - Gu\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\lVert u-m \rVert^2_{C} \end{align}

where y∈Rny \in \R^ny∈Rn and m∈Rdm \in \R^dm∈Rd are fixed vectors, G∈Rn×dG \in \R^{n \times d}G∈Rn×d is the linear forward model, and Σ∈Rn×n\Sigma \in \R^{n \times n}Σ∈Rn×n and C∈Rd×dC \in \R^{d \times d}C∈Rd×d are positive definite matrices. In (1) we have used the following notation for inner products and norms weighted by a positive definite matrix CCC: \begin{align} \langle v, v^\prime \rangle_C &:= \langle C^{-1}v, v^\prime\rangle = v^\top C^{-1}v^\prime \newline \lVert v \rVert_C^2 &:= \langle v, v\rangle_C. \end{align}

A solution to (1) can be viewed as a maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimate under the Bayesian model \begin{align} y|u &\sim \mathcal{N}(Gu, \Sigma) \tag{3} \newline u &\sim \mathcal{N}(m, C). \tag{4} \end{align}

I discuss this problem in depth in my post, on the linear Gaussian model, where I show that the solution can be written as the following equivalent expressions, \begin{align} u_{\star} &= \left(G^\top \Sigma^{-1}G + C^{-1}\right)^{-1}\left(G^\top \Sigma^{-1}y + C^{-1}m \right) \tag{5} \newline u_{\star} &= m + CG^\top \left(GCG^\top + \Sigma \right)^{-1}(y-Gm). \tag{6} \end{align}

In this post we will consider a generalization of problem (1), where CCC is only required to be positive semidefinite (not strictly positive definite). In particular, this means that the inverse C−1C^{-1}C−1 may not exist. It is interesting to note that, although (5) depends on C−1C^{-1}C−1, the inverse does not appear anywhere in the equivalent expression (6). This leads to the natural question of whether (6) still provides a valid solution to the optimization problem even when CCC is singular. The first step in investigating this question will be providing a suitable generalization of the objective function in (1), since the expression ∥u−m∥C2=∥C−1/2(u−m)∥2\lVert u - m\rVert^2_{C} = \lVert C^{-1/2}(u - m)\rVert^2∥u−m∥C2​=∥C−1/2(u−m)∥2 is not well-defined when CCC is singular.

Generalizing the Optimization Problem

Our goal is now to extend (1) to the case where CCC need not be strictly positive definite. We start by generalizing (1) through the definition of a constrained optimization problem on an extended parameter space. We then provide two approaches to formulate this problem in an unconstrained fashion, each of which leads to equivalent closed-from solutions. We will find it convenient to define notation for the “centered” quantities \begin{align} &u^\prime := u - m, &&y^\prime := y - Gm \tag{7} \end{align} so that y−Gu=(y−Gm)−G(u−m)=y′−Gu′.(8) y - Gu = (y - Gm) - G(u-m) = y^\prime - Gu^\prime. \tag{8} y−Gu=(y−Gm)−G(u−m)=y′−Gu′.(8)

Constrained Formulation

We start by considering the constrained formulation. This section follows the approach in section 8.1.2 of (Sanz-Alonso et al., 2023). To start, note that when CCC is positive definite, we have ∥u−m∥C2=∥u′∥C2=⟨C−1u′,u′⟩=⟨b,u′⟩,(9) \lVert u - m\rVert^2_C = \lVert u^\prime \rVert^2_C = \langle C^{-1}u^\prime, u^\prime\rangle = \langle b, u^\prime \rangle, \tag{9} ∥u−m∥C2​=∥u′∥C2​=⟨C−1u′,u′⟩=⟨b,u′⟩,(9) where b∈Rdb \in \mathbb{R}^db∈Rd solves Cb=u′.(10) Cb = u^\prime. \tag{10} Cb=u′.(10) When CCC is invertible, the unique bbb solving (10) is simply found by multiplying both sides by C−1C^{-1}C−1. When CCC is not invertible, then there may be zero or infinitely many such solutions. As long as there is at least one solution to (10) we can give meaning to expression (9) by picking a particular bbb that solves (10). Now that we have introduced a new variable bbb, we might consider generalizing (1) by jointly optimizing over (u,b)(u,b)(u,b) subject to the linear constraint Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′.

Constrained Joint Optimization.
\begin{align} (u_{\star}, b_{\star}) &\in \text{argmin}_{(u,b) \in \mathcal{S}} J(u,b) \tag{11} \newline J(u,b) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - Gu\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\langle b, u-m \rangle \newline \mathcal{S} &:= \left\{(u,b) : Cb = u-m \right\}. \end{align}

Note that if CCC is positive definite, then (11) reduces to (1). If the problem is solved for (u⋆,b⋆)(u_{\star}, b_{\star})(u⋆​,b⋆​), then the desired solution can be obtained by extracting u⋆u_{\star}u⋆​ and discarding the nuisance parameter b⋆b_{\star}b⋆​.

Lagrange Multipliers

Observe that (11) can be viewed as optimizing J(u,b)J(u,b)J(u,b) subject to the constraint g(u,b)=0g(u,b) = 0g(u,b)=0, where g(u,b)=Cb−(u−m)g(u,b) = Cb - (u-m)g(u,b)=Cb−(u−m). This is a typical setup for Lagrange multipliers. We therefore introduce the Lagrange multiplier λ∈Rd\lambda \in \mathbb{R}^dλ∈Rd, which allows us to cast the constrained optimization over (u,b)(u,b)(u,b) as an unconstrained optimization over (u,b,λ)(u,b,\lambda)(u,b,λ).

Lagrange Multiplier Formulation.
\begin{align} (u_{\star}, b_{\star}, \lambda_{\star}) &\in \text{argmin}_{u,b,\lambda} J(u,b,\lambda) \tag{12} \newline J(u,b,\lambda) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - Gu\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\langle b, u-m \rangle + \langle \lambda, Cb - u + m \rangle. \end{align}

We have succeeding in converting the problem to one that can be solved by analytical means; namely, by solving the system of equations ∇uJ=∇bJ=∇λJ=0.(13) \nabla_{u} J = \nabla_{b} J = \nabla_{\lambda} J = 0. \tag{13} ∇u​J=∇b​J=∇λ​J=0.(13)

This derivation is provided in the appendix, and the result is summarized below.

Solution of Lagrange Multiplier Formulation.
A solution (u⋆,b⋆,λ⋆)(u_{\star}, b_{\star}, \lambda_{\star})(u⋆​,b⋆​,λ⋆​) of (12), projected onto the uuu-component, is given by u⋆=m+Cb⋆,(14) u_{\star} = m + Cb_{\star}, \tag{14} u⋆​=m+Cb⋆​,(14) where b⋆=[(G⊤Σ−1G)C+I]−1G⊤Σ−1(y−Gm).(15) b_{\star} = \left[(G^\top \Sigma^{-1}G)C + I \right]^{-1}G^\top \Sigma^{-1}(y-Gm). \tag{15} b⋆​=[(G⊤Σ−1G)C+I]−1G⊤Σ−1(y−Gm).(15) It also holds that C[(G⊤Σ−1G)C+I]−1G⊤Σ−1=CG⊤(GCG⊤+Σ)−1,(16) C\left[(G^\top \Sigma^{-1}G)C + I \right]^{-1}G^\top \Sigma^{-1} = CG^\top \left(GCG^\top + \Sigma \right)^{-1}, \tag{16} C[(G⊤Σ−1G)C+I]−1G⊤Σ−1=CG⊤(GCG⊤+Σ)−1,(16) which implies that (14) agrees with expression (6).

Basis Approach

We now consider an alternative approach that avoids the joint optimization over (u,b)(u,b)(u,b). Similar exposition can be found in section 8.3 of (Evensen et al., 2022). Looking back to (9), instead of choosing to optimize over all bbb satisfying (10), we will instead simply choose a particular bbb satisfying this constraint. This only makes sense if the particular choice of bbb does not matter; i.e., if the value of ⟨b,u′⟩\langle b, u^\prime \rangle⟨b,u′⟩ is the same for any bbb solving (10). The below propostion shows that this is indeed the case.

Proposition.
Let u∈Rdu \in \mathbb{R}^du∈Rd be a vector such that there is at least one solution b∈Rdb \in \mathbb{R}^db∈Rd to Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′. Then ⟨b,u′⟩\langle b, u^\prime \rangle⟨b,u′⟩ and J(u,b)J(u,b)J(u,b) are constant for any choice of bbb solving this linear system.

Proof. Let b,b′∈Rdb, b^\prime \in \R^db,b′∈Rd satisfy Cb=Cb′=u′Cb = Cb^\prime = u^\primeCb=Cb′=u′. It thus follows that ⟨b,u′⟩−⟨b′,u′⟩=⟨b−b′,u′⟩=⟨b−b′,Cb⟩=⟨C(b−b′),b⟩=⟨0,b⟩=0, \langle b, u^\prime\rangle - \langle b^\prime, u^\prime\rangle = \langle b - b^\prime, u^\prime\rangle = \langle b - b^\prime, Cb\rangle = \langle C(b - b^\prime), b\rangle = \langle 0, b\rangle = 0, ⟨b,u′⟩−⟨b′,u′⟩=⟨b−b′,u′⟩=⟨b−b′,Cb⟩=⟨C(b−b′),b⟩=⟨0,b⟩=0, where we have used the linearity of the inner product and the fact that CCC is symmetric. Since the inner product term in (11) is the only portion with dependence on bbb, it follows that J(v,b)=J(v,b′)J(v,b) = J(v,b^\prime)J(v,b)=J(v,b′). ■\qquad \blacksquare■

Thus, for each uuu that yields a consistent system Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′, we can simply pick any solution bbb to insert into ⟨b,u′⟩\langle b, u^\prime\rangle⟨b,u′⟩. The objective will be well-defined since the above result verifies that the specific choice of bbb is inconsequential. A natural choice is to select the bbb of minimal norm; that is, b†:=argminCb=u′∥b∥.(17) b^{\dagger} := \text{argmin}_{Cb=u^\prime} \lVert b \rVert. \tag{17} b†:=argminCb=u′​∥b∥.(17) This unique minimal norm solution is guaranteed to exist and is conveniently given by the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse b†=C†u′.(18) b^{\dagger} = C^{\dagger}u^\prime. \tag{18} b†=C†u′.(18) Note that when CCC is positive definite, C†=C−1C^{\dagger} = C^{-1}C†=C−1. We can now eliminate the requirement to optimize over bbb by considering the following optimization problem.

Pseudoinverse Formulation.
\begin{align} u_{\star} &\in \text{argmin}_{u \in \mathcal{S}} J(u) \tag{19} \newline J(u) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - Gu\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\langle C^{\dagger}(u-m), u-m \rangle \newline \mathcal{S} &:= \left\{u \in \mathbb{R}^d: u-m \in \mathcal{R}(C) \right\} \end{align}

Note that we are now required to reintroduce a constraint set S\mathcal{S}S. This is due to the fact that the pseudoinverse produces a solution bbb to Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′ when a solution exists, but we must still explicitly restrict the search space to uuu that admit a consistent system Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′; i.e., u′∈R(C)u^\prime \in \mathcal{R}(C)u′∈R(C). The previous approach dealt with this issue by introducing a Lagrange multiplier λ\lambdaλ. We now show that (18) can be written as an unconstrained problem without extending the parameter space. This relies on the following important fact.

Subspace Property.
Let A∈Rd×rA \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times r}A∈Rd×r be a matrix of rank r≤dr \leq dr≤d satisfying C=AA⊤C = AA^\topC=AA⊤. Then a solution to the optimization problem (19) is constrained to the rrr-dimensional affine subspace m+R(C)=m+R(A).(20) m + \mathcal{R}(C) = m + \mathcal{R}(A). \tag{20} m+R(C)=m+R(A).(20)

To implicitly encode the constraint u′∈R(C)u^\prime \in \mathcal{R}(C)u′∈R(C), we can look for solutions in m+R(A)m + \mathcal{R}(A)m+R(A). Any vector in this space can be written as u=m+∑j=1rwjaj=m+Aw,(21) u = m + \sum_{j=1}^{r} w_j a_j = m + Aw, \tag{21} u=m+j=1∑r​wj​aj​=m+Aw,(21) for some weight vector w:=(w1,…,wr)⊤∈Rrw := (w_1, \dots, w_r)^\top \in \mathbb{R}^rw:=(w1​,…,wr​)⊤∈Rr. We have successfully shown that the optimum (6) continues to hold for the generalization (11) of the least squares formulation, even when CCC is singular. Uniqueness

If the solution set S\mathcal{S}S is non-empty, then there is a unique optimal value u⋆u_{\star}u⋆​ solving (11).

Why should we even care about the case when CCC is singular? The main application that motivated this post comes from the field of data assimilation. If we define AAA to be the d×rd \times rd×r matrix with jthj^{\text{th}}jth row equal to 1r−1(u(j)−m)\frac{1}{\sqrt{r-1}}\left(u^{(j)} - m\right)r−1​1​(u(j)−m), then we see that C=AA⊤C = AA^\topC=AA⊤. We derive expressions (14), (15) and (16), the latter showing that the solution agrees with (6).

We start by computing the gradients with respect to uuu, bbb, and λ\lambdaλ: \begin{align} \nabla_{u}J &= -G^\top \Sigma^{-1}(y-Gu) + \frac{1}{2}b - \lambda \tag{31} \newline \nabla_{b}J &= \frac{1}{2}u^\prime + C\lambda \newline \nabla_{\lambda}J &= Cb - u^\prime. \end{align} where we recall the definition u′:=u−mu^\prime := u - mu′:=u−m. We now show that (36) agrees with the standard least squares solution (6). entry.title: Markov Melding
entry.content:
In this post, I summarize a technique called Markov melding, originally proposed in Goudie et al (2023).

Motivation and Setup

Models of complex systems (climate, disease, etc.) are typically composed of many sub-models. For example, climate models couple together models of the atmosphere, land, ocean, and cryosphere. The component models may be developed largely in isolation, before being combined with the others to form a complex model for the whole system. In the context of Markov melding, we are considering that these component models are specified within a Bayesian framework, so that each component can be identified with a joint probability distribution of the component model parameters and data. Letting MMM denote the number of components, we denote the density for the joint distribution of the mthm^{\text{th}}mth submodel by \begin{align} &p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m), &&m = 1, \dots, M \tag{1} \end{align} where YmY_mYm​ denotes the data used in the mthm^{\text{th}}mth submodel. The submodel parameters are θm:=(ϕ,ψm),(2) \theta_m := (\phi, \psi_m), \tag{2} θm​:=(ϕ,ψm​),(2) and we make a distinction between component-specific parameters ψm\psi_mψm​ and parameters ϕ\phiϕ that are shared across all submodels. Goudie et al (2019) refer to ϕ\phiϕ as the link parameters. A typical modeling workflow might involve obtaining the posterior distributions pm(ϕ,ψm∣Ym)p_m(\phi, \psi_m|Y_m)pm​(ϕ,ψm​∣Ym​) for each submodel independently, and then combining them post-hoc in some fashion to study the system as a whole. Bayesian melding is an alternative approach that seeks to construct a joint distribution p(ϕ,ψ1,…,ψm,Y1,…,Ym)p(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_m, Y_1, \dots, Y_m)p(ϕ,ψ1​,…,ψm​,Y1​,…,Ym​) that combines all components into a unified probabilistic model. Then inference can proceed by characterizing the posterior distribution p(ϕ,ψ1,…,ψm∣Y1,…,Ym)p(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_m | Y_1, \dots, Y_m)p(ϕ,ψ1​,…,ψm​∣Y1​,…,Ym​). The key distinction here is that all of the data Y1,…,YmY_1, \dots, Y_mY1​,…,Ym​ is used to inform the parameters across all components. The isolated component posterior pm(ϕ,ψm∣Ym)p_m(\phi, \psi_m|Y_m)pm​(ϕ,ψm​∣Ym​) might look quite different from p(ϕ,ψm∣Y1,…,Ym)p(\phi, \psi_m|Y_1, \dots, Y_m)p(ϕ,ψm​∣Y1​,…,Ym​) due to the influence of the other components.

On a final note before proceeding with the method, we emphasize the assumption that ϕ\phiϕ is the only link between the submodels. From a probabilistic standpoint, this implies that we will be considering joint distributions with the property that component-specific variables in any two distinct models are conditionally independent given the link parameter ϕ\phiϕ; symbolically, (ψm,Ym)⊥(ψℓ,Yℓ)∣ϕ,m≠ℓ.(3) (\psi_m, Y_m) \perp (\psi_\ell, Y_\ell) | \phi, \qquad m \neq \ell. \tag{3} (ψm​,Ym​)⊥(ψℓ​,Yℓ​)∣ϕ,m​=ℓ.(3)

Markov Combination

We start with the assumption that the submodels are consistent in the sense that they all imply the same prior distribution on the link parameter ϕ\phiϕ; i.e., p1(ϕ)=⋯=pM(ϕ).(4) p_1(\phi) = \cdots = p_M(\phi). \tag{4} p1​(ϕ)=⋯=pM​(ϕ).(4) The method of constructing a joint distribution under assumption (4) is referred to as Markov combination (Dawid and Lauritzen, 1993). This assumption makes the definition of a joint distribution relatively straightforward. Denoting the common prior on the link parameter by p(ϕ):=pm(ϕ)p(\phi) := p_m(\phi)p(ϕ):=pm​(ϕ), the Markov combination approach defines a joint distribution pcombp_{\text{comb}}pcomb​ by \begin{align} p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M) &:= p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M|\phi)p(\phi) \newline &:= p(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_m(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi). \tag{5} \end{align} We emphasize the both of the above equalities are definitions, though both definitions are quite natural in this setting. The first ensures that the common prior p(ϕ)p(\phi)p(ϕ) is preserved by the joint distribution, while the second defines the conditional density (conditional on ϕ\phiϕ) using the conditional independence properties noted in (3). This ensures the submodel distributions pm(ϕ,ψm,Ym)p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m)pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​) are also preserved. Specifically, (5) satisfies pcomb(ϕ,ψm,Ym)=pm(ϕ,ψm,Ym),m=1,…,M.(6) p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) = p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m), \qquad m = 1, \dots, M. \tag{6} pcomb​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)=pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​),m=1,…,M.(6) It will be useful to rewrite (5) as \begin{align} p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M) &= p(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_m(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi) \newline &= p(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} \frac{p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m)}{p(\phi)} \newline &= \frac{1}{p(\phi)^{M-1}} \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m), \tag{7} \end{align} which shows that pcombp_{\text{comb}}pcomb​ is just the product of the submodel distributions pmp_mpm​, normalized by p(ϕ)M−1p(\phi)^{M-1}p(ϕ)M−1 to account for the fact that the prior p(ϕ)p(\phi)p(ϕ) is multiplied MMM times in the product. From the expression (7), we may easily verify (6); letting ψ−m:=(ψ1,…,ψm−1,ψm+1,…,ψM)\psi_{-m} := (\psi_1, \dots, \psi_{m-1}, \psi_{m+1}, \dots, \psi_M)ψ−m​:=(ψ1​,…,ψm−1​,ψm+1​,…,ψM​) and similarly for Y−mY_{-m}Y−m​, we obtain \begin{align} p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) &= \int p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M) d\psi_{-m}dY_{-m} \newline &= \frac{1}{p(\phi)^{M-1}}p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) \prod_{\ell \neq m} \int p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) d\psi_\ell dY_\ell \newline &= \frac{1}{p(\phi)^{M-1}}p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) \prod_{\ell \neq m} p_\ell(\phi) \newline &= \frac{1}{p(\phi)^{M-1}}p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) p(\phi)^{M-1} \newline &= p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m). \end{align}

While the definition (5) seems somewhat natural, one may wish for a more quantitative justification. To this end, Massa and Lauritzen (2010) show that pcombp_{\text{comb}}pcomb​ has maximal entropy among all distributions satisfying the MMM constraints (6). Loosely speaking, this tells us that pcombp_{\text{comb}}pcomb​ is the least constrained of all the distributions satisfying (6), a desirable property in the absence of additional knowledge on the relative merits of the submodels.

Markov Melding

Goudie et al (2019) consider propose a generalization of Markov combination to the setting where the marginals pm(ϕ)p_m(\phi)pm​(ϕ) may not be consistent across submodels. In this case, we can no longer simply pull out the common prior in the first line of definition (5). To address this, the authors’ propose first replacing the marginals pm(ϕ)p_m(\phi)pm​(ϕ) with a common “pooled” prior ppool(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)ppool​(ϕ). After performing this “marginal replacement”, Markov combination can then be applied with respect to the modified submodels.

Marginal Replacement

We first consider modifying the submodels to ensure they are consistent with respect to the marginal of the link parameter. The idea is to replace the original submodels pm(ϕ,ψm,Ym)=pm(ϕ)pm(ψm,Ym∣ϕ) p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) = p_m(\phi) p_m(\psi_m, Y_m | \phi) pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)=pm​(ϕ)pm​(ψm​,Ym​∣ϕ) with modifications that share a common ϕ\phiϕ-marginal: \begin{align} p_{\text{repl},m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) &:= p_{\text{pool}}(\phi) p_m(\psi_m, Y_m | \phi) \tag{8} \newline &= \frac{p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)}{p_m(\phi)} p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m). \tag{9} \end{align} We see in (8) that the submodel conditional (on ϕ\phiϕ) is unchanged by the marginal replacement. The expression (9) gives an alternative viewpoint, where we view the original joint submodel distribution pmp_mpm​ as re-weighted by some modification factor ppool(ϕ)/pm(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)/p_m(\phi)ppool​(ϕ)/pm​(ϕ). This, of course, begs the question of how to choose ppool(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)ppool​(ϕ).
